newsitem.title: USA: Younger Kennedys admit alcohol problem - magazine.
newsitem.headline: Younger Kennedys admit alcohol problem - magazine.

text.p: A member of the Kennedy family said in an interview published on Monday it was easier for the young generation of the Kennedys to "get an Alcoholics Anonymous (A.A.) meeting together than a touch-football team."

In an interview with Vanity Fair as part of an article on the troubles afflicting some of the children of the late Sen. Robert Kennedy, 34-year-old son Christopher said his siblings were well aware of the moral ramifications of their actions and that alcohol definitely played a role.

Christopher Kennedy, whose brother Michael has been accused in press reports of having an affair with his children's teenage babysitter, was quoted as saying: "No one has hidden behind alcoholism as an excuse for inappropriate behaviour.
"But all of us clearly understand the link. And in cases where alcohol contributed to inappropriate behaviour -- in every case -- these people don't drink anymore."
He said that least eight or nine members of his immediate family of 28 siblings and cousins or their spouses attend daily A.A. meetings.
"And clearly a number of them have spent time in rehab clinics around the country. And there's a fair number who've sought conclusive advice from doctors and pyschiatrists," he said.

He added: "The combination of those is an almost unparalleled examination into the forces that affect our lives, a much more serious one than you could imagine. It's done individually, it's done as a group and it's almost ... endless."
He said that at the family compound in Hyannis Port, "It's easier to get an A.A. meeting together than a touch-football game now."
